Built to defend the airspace of the cold northern nÃƒÂ¤tion ÃƒÂ¶f Kweden, where young Kerbals are taught to fight polar beÃƒÂ¤rs and umlauts reign supreme, the KAAB 37 Thunderbolt is intended to serve where other fighter jets cÃƒÂ¤nnot: on icy windswept airfields, cracked asphÃƒÂ¥lt roads, even dirt and gravel runways in the middle of the fÃƒÂ¶rest!

*Inspired by the Swedish SAAB 37 'Viggen' (Thunderbolt)*

**Specifications**

Mass: 15.7t

**Operational Guide**

**Commands**

1 - Toggle engine

2 - Drop fuel tank

**Takeoff**

Takeoff is a very straightforwÃƒÂ¥rd procedure: just commence rotation as soon as possible. The KAAB 37 is ÃƒÂ¤ble to fly at very low airspeeds.

**Flight**

The KAAB 37 is an extraordinarily stable fighter. It also turns relÃƒÂ¥tively well. As we say in Kweden: "just enÃƒÂ¶ugh is best". Do not be afraid of exceeding the structural integrity of the aircrÃƒÂ¥ft in high speed maneuvers - it's simply impossible!

**Landing**

Drop the external fuel tÃƒÂ¤nk before landing. Approach the runway at around 100-120 m/s, fÃƒÂ¶r the final approach, lower this speed to around 70-80 m/s.

Excellent job. My only critique is that, unless this is supposed to be the KAAB AJS37, the tail should be dogtoothed and have a pitot for the artificial feel system pressure head.
Do you have your own company? I'd like to see more where this came from ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif) +rep

> 
> Excellent job. My only critique is that, unless this is supposed to be the KAAB AJS37, the tail should be dogtoothed and have a pitot for the artificial feel system pressure head.

Thanks! I'm not overly familiar with aircraft technical terms, what is an 'artificial feel system pressure head'? ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif)

Anyway, I can add a pitot on the vertical stabilizer?

> 
> Do you have your own company? I'd like to see more where this came from ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif) +rep

For now I'd like to keep them separate until I build up something that more resembles a launch library if you will, then I could start an actual 'company thread'.

> For now I'd like to keep them separate until I build up something that more resembles a launch library if you will, then I could start an actual 'company thread'.

Support you on that:D
Nicely done! ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif) Are you going to build anything after SAAB?

> 
> Thanks! I'm not overly familiar with aircraft technical terms, what is an 'artificial feel system pressure head'? ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif)
> Anyway, I can add a pitot on the vertical stabilizer?

The Viggen used one of the world's first digital flight control computers (the Honeywell-SAAB SA07). The AFS pressure head feeds airspeed and other data to the SA07 independent of the other sensors so the pilot would have some sort of feedback on the stick.

You can see the pitot and the slight dogtooth in the side view of this image [here](http://www.aviastar.org/pictures/sweden/saab_viggen.gif).

> 
> The Viggen used one of the world's first digital flight control computers (the Honeywell-SAAB SA07). The AFS pressure head feeds airspeed and other data to the SA07 independent of the other sensors so the pilot would have some sort of feedback on the stick.
> You can see the pitot and the slight dogtooth in the side view of this image [here](http://www.aviastar.org/pictures/sweden/saab_viggen.gif).

Interesting, I always appreciate learning more about my favorite planes. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)
